message.content:
<teammate-message teammate_id="team-lead" summary="Vote: constitutive character → shortened to character">
The author proposes: introduce "constitutive character (德 De)" at first occurrence with a TN that explicitly tells the reader it will be shortened to "character" in the following paragraphs. Then use plain "character" throughout the rest of the text.

This gives:
- Precision at introduction (constitutive character)
- Lightweight running text (character)
- Reader is explicitly told about the shortening, so no confusion

YES or NO? Brief response.
</teammate-message>

input.content: **YES.** This is exactly what I have been arguing for. Precision where it matters, brevity where it recurs, reader explicitly informed of the convention.

routing.content: **YES.** This is exactly what I have been arguing for. Precision where it matters, brevity where it recurs, reader explicitly informed of the convention.

content.text: YES. This is the solution I have been advocating: full precision at introduction, lightweight single word in running text, explicit reader notification of the shortening convention.
